notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): (p. 5) misericordes ; quomodo sicut et pater uester; | misericors est

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (p. 5) Ernnostlice wese ge mildheorte | hu gemete. swá swá eowre heofonlic fedur mild | heorte is

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: (p. 7) 7 rixað on weorulde | weoruld. amen. seo hit swa.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): (p. 7) In illo tempore ; Cum turba inruerent ad | iesum ut audirent uerbumdei

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (p. 7) On ðam tide mid ði þæt folc geðrungon to ðem | helende

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: (p. 2) 7 drihtin blitsiende on | weorolde weruld seo hit efre swa ; buton eg | hwilcum ende. amen

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): (p. 2) [I]N illo tempore ; Dixit iesus discipulis suis;

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (p. 2) On | ðam tyde se helend cwæð to his lernunge | cnihtas

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: (p. 4) 7 rixað on weorulde werold seo hit swa bu | ton eghwilcum ende amen

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): (p. 4) [I]N illo tempore ; Cum turba multa esset cum | iesu ; et reliqua.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (p. 4) On ðam tyde mycel folc wes | mid þem helende. 7 he ne hafdon hwet he | aton

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: (p.4) Gif ic forlete heom | festende faren on here husas þonne te | orgon he on wege;

objectDesc.extent:
c. 245 mm x 185 mm (dimensions of all - size of leaves).
c. 205 mm x 135 mm (dimensions of all - size of written space).

hands.name: main text
hands.description: Pages 1-8. 'Anglo-Saxon minuscule of an unpretentious kind' (

characters.note: a is usually insular in the Old English and the Latin, and is often tear-drop shaped. On one occasion a tall-backed Caroline a is used.
The ascender of b has a tag to the left.
d is round-backed in English, with an upstroke that is higher than earlier eleventh-century minuscule. Round-backed d is also used in the Latin on occasion.
f is insular in the English script and Caroline in Latin. In the former, the middle stroke of f is longer than the headstroke.

g is usually insular with a rounded, nearly circular bowl in the English. The tail begins from the middle of the headstroke. A distinctive Caroline g appears in the Latin with a large, sweeping and unclosed tail.
The ascender of h has a tag to the left. The form is insular in both Latin and English.
The ascender of l has a mannered finial.
s is low or high in both English and Latin.
The ascender of þ has a tag to the left.
The upstroke of ð is the same height as other ascenders. The cross-stroke starts from the right of the upstroke.
y is straight-limbed, formed with two strokes and often dotted.
ascenders are straight and wedged, tagged to the left, or slightly split.
descenders are straight and very occasionally have the slightest curve to the left.
punctuation is most frequently the punctus, placed at medial height; the punctus versus, with a long comma; and the punctus elevatus, with a good deal of space between the punctus and the tick.

Abbreviations are denoted by a very characteristic straight macron, placed a few millimetres above the graph. The abbreviation for 'that' is notable: the oblique line through the ascender of þ is very straight.
There are a few examples of the ct ligature, written so that the two letters are very separate from each other, and one of the final nt ligatures.

history.provenance: The wearing at the edge and the incisions found in the writing area of the folios may suggest that they were used as wrappings or covers of other documents.
history.acquisition: It is unknown when the Somerset Archaeological and Natural History Society acquired the manuscript, but it must have been after its foundation in 1849.

admin: Manuscript described by Elaine Treharne with the assistance of Hollie Morgan (August 2010; September 2012).
